dlgLine.text: How can I help?

dlgAnsw.text: The bus is ready to go. Let's start getting everyone loaded on.
The plane's ready to go. We should start loading people onto a bus and getting them to the airport.
I have the medical supplies we need.
I have the parts for the signal booster for the radio.
I need to ration the shelter's food for a little while.
Anything that would improve your mood?
Can I ask you a question?
We'll talk later.

dlgLine.text: Of course.

dlgAnsw.text: Where am I?
What else can you tell me about the weeks before I got here?
What can you tell me about the people here?
How should we improve this place?
What else can you tell me about yourself?
We'll talk later.

dlgLine.text: Think you're up to talking about our situation now?

dlgAnsw.text: Sure.
Let's get this over with.
Give me a minute...

dlgLine.text: Whenever you're ready.

dlgAnsw.text: Thanks.
Alright.

dlgLine.text: Good. I'll get the others.

dlgAnsw.text: <Davis motions to Anita...>

dlgLine.text: You're in Texas - a town called Splendid. They evacuated the town, so we're all that's left. It's a long story... we should talk about this when we have more time.

dlgAnsw.text: I have another question.
That's all I needed to know. See ya.

dlgLine.text: Joel and I are locals. Joel's a police officer and I've worked here at the school. Anita and Renee ran out of gas not far from here - I picked up their distress call on the radio.
We picked up another survivor in the plane crash, but he hasn't woken up yet. I guess we'll have to wait and see if he recovers.
The other woman, that's Elaine. She's been through a lot. Maybe you should try talking to her.
Just be patient - they're a lot stronger than you think.

dlgAnsw.text: I have another question.
I see. I should go.

dlgLine.text: Well, it all happened rather quickly, to be honest. One day the news was reporting about a mystery illness, the next they were talking about travel restrictions and civil unrest. All of a sudden the nation was under martial law and major cities were being evacuated.
Like most people, I didn't really believe the dead were coming back to life until I saw it for myself. I guess that's how it's gotten this bad.
We're dealing with it as best we can for a town this size... I'd like to hope the rest of the world is doing the same.

dlgAnsw.text: Another question...
I see. Thanks. That's it for now.

dlgLine.text: Hmm... Well, I can think of a couple of things, but most of all, I think people will be happier if they feel safe. Though, it might be important for you to ask around and see what the others want.
Keeping the school stocked with food, fuel, medical supplies, creature comforts, and other items would go a long way around here.

dlgAnsw.text: Okay. I had something else I wanted to ask.
Hmm... I should go do that now.

dlgLine.text: Me? You mean you want to know how I ended up in this chair?

dlgAnsw.text: No, that's not necessary.
Okay.

dlgLine.text: It's alright...

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: I was a firefighter. When I was younger, our car flipped... My mother died, but a fireman saved my life. I always wanted to be that person that pulled the little boy out of the wreck...
And I became a pretty good one, maybe a little too devoted to the job. It takes its toll.
It was about eight years ago, my wife had just left with our daughter. The fire was at a local farm, during drought conditions. We were trying to get the livestock out, when I heard a boy's cries.
I don't know what I was thinking - that I could be like that man that saved me or that my heroics would get my wife back... Anyhow, I went deeper into the barn, knowing I had to save that boy.
I did get him out, but as I was running out with him, a beam fell... It crushed my spine. I never walked again.

For a long time, I felt defeated, like my life was over. But then I started working in the library here at the school, and I eventually made peace with my situation. When the crisis began, I felt those old instincts - like I could make a difference and...
I'm talking your ear off - sorry.

dlgAnsw.text: So you can't walk at all? You're stuck here.
No problem. I had another question.
I'm sure you'll do whatever you can. We'll talk later.

dlgLine.text: Let me check... Nope, still aren't working.
But seriously, if I could walk, I'd be out there with you. I can keep an eye things here while you're gone, though.

dlgAnsw.text: Good to know. I had another question.
Just checking. I should go.

dlgLine.text: Great.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -
- New Answ -

dlgLine.text: We'd be better off if Renee was here, but I'll see what I can do.

dlgAnsw.text: <Davis takes the medical supplies and begins to look through them.>

dlgLine.text: I'll give these to Renee. I'm sure she'll have our mystery man on his feet in no time.

dlgAnsw.text: <Davis takes the medical supplies and begins to look through them.>

dlgLine.text: I wish I could call my daughter, but... More realistically, I guess I could use real coffee beans - that would make monitoring the radio easier. Deodorant would be nice - gets a bit hot in here most days.

dlgAnsw.text: Here's some whole bean coffee.
I have some deodorant.
I'll let you know if I come across any.

dlgLine.text: I appreciate this. And I think it will make the school smell a whole lot better.

dlgAnsw.text: You're welcome. See ya.
Glad it helps.

dlgLine.text: Ah... smells like civilization. It's the little things, right?

dlgAnsw.text: Yup. Enjoy, Davis.
If only everyone here worried about how they smell. See ya.

dlgLine.text: Excellent. The manual I'm working from is kind of old and vague, but I think with these I ought to get things up and running in about three days. I'll let you know when I've got it working.

dlgAnsw.text: <Davis pulls out the radio manual.>

dlgLine.text: Are you sure you're ready to go? We don't know what me might hit on the road, so you may want to make sure everyone's armed and you've got personnel assigned to duty.

dlgAnsw.text: I'm ready as I'll ever be. Let's go.
You're right - I'll get everyone suited up and make the final picks for my team.

dlgLine.text: Are you sure you're ready to go? We don't know what me might hit on the road, so you may want to make sure everyone's armed and you've got personnel assigned to duty.

dlgAnsw.text: I'm ready as I'll ever be. Let's go.
You're right - I'll get everyone suited up and make the final picks for my team.

dlgLine.text: I'll let everyone know.
It's hard to believe we're leaving. I know it's only been a few months, but it feels like years. And this place, for everything that's happened, has started to feel like a home.
If it wasn't for you, I'm not sure how things would have turned out. I know it hasn't been easy...

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -
- New Answ -

dlgLine.text: Especially after your loss on the plane. It took real fortitude to step up after that.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: So... <charname> - think you can save our lives one more time?

dlgAnsw.text: It's why I'm in charge, isn't it?
I'm not thinking about what obstacles we might hit - I just want to finally get out of here.
I've gotten too good at killing people... Hopefully, I won't have to do that anymore.
If anyone's still stupid enough to get in our way, I've perfected a cure for that. Leave it to me.

dlgLine.text: I'll do a final sweep to make sure we haven't forgot anything. See you on the bus.

dlgAnsw.text: <Davis goes back to his checklist. You grab your gear and head out to the bus.>

dlgLine.text: I'll let everyone know.
It's hard to believe we're leaving. I know it's only been a few months, but it feels like years. And this place, for everything that's happened, has started to feel like a home.
If it wasn't for you, I'm not sure how things would have turned out. I know it hasn't been easy...

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -
- New Answ -

dlgLine.text: Especially after your loss on the plane. It took real fortitude to step up after that. I'm surprised you can even board another one.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: So... <charname> - think you can save our lives one more time?

dlgAnsw.text: It's why I'm in charge, isn't it?
I'm not thinking about what obstacles we might hit - I just want to finally get out of here.
I've gotten too good at killing people... Hopefully, I won't have to do that anymore.
If anyone's still stupid enough to get in our way, I've perfected a cure for that. Leave it to me.

dlgLine.text: I'll do a final sweep to make sure we haven't forgot anything. See you on the plane.

dlgAnsw.text: <Davis goes back to his checklist. You grab your gear and head out to your vehicle.>

dlgLine.text: We can cut rations for a short time, but it won't help morale. How long should we ration food for?

dlgAnsw.text: Ration food for 1 day.
Ration food for 3 days.
Ration food for 5 days.
Forget it. We don't need morale to drop any lower right now.

dlgLine.text: Understood. I'll make sure everyone knows.

dlgAnsw.text: <Davis makes a note on his supply list.>
